## 1. Typical design parameters of a street‑level 5G small cell

| Parameter | Typical value (ranges you will see in vendor data‑sheets or deployment guidelines) |
|-----------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Transmit power (EIRP)** | 10 W – 40 W (i.e., 10 dBW – 16 dBW) for the **sub‑6 GHz** band; 2 W – 10 W for the **mmWave** band. |

| **Mounting height** | 4 m – 8 m above ground (on a lamp‑post or building façade). |
| **Typical operating scenario** | The antenna forms narrow beams that track a user’s phone; when no user is in the immediate vicinity the radiated power is automatically reduced (dynamic power control). |

*Note:* The numbers above are **conservative** (i.e., on the high side) because many operators deliberately limit the effective isotropic radiated power (EIRP) of street‑level nodes to keep the “public exposure” well under the regulatory ceiling.

## 2. Simple far‑field calculation (sub‑6 GHz example)

The **far‑field power‑density** at a distance *r* from an isotropic radiator is  

\[
S(r)=\frac{P_{\text{EIRP}}}{4\pi r^{2}} \quad\text{[W·m}^{-2}\text{]}
\]

where \(P_{\text{EIRP}} = P_{\text{Tx}} \times G\) (transmit power times antenna gain).
